name: Chocolate Hills
description: A geological formation of more than 1,200 perfectly cone-shaped hills that turn chocolate-brown during the dry season, creating a unique landscape.
longDescription:
The Chocolate Hills are one of the Philippines' most iconic natural wonders, consisting of at least 1,268 perfectly cone-shaped hills spread over an area of more than 50 square kilometers. These unusual geological formations, which range from 30 to 120 meters in height, are covered in green grass that turns brown during the dry season, giving them the appearance of chocolate moundsâ€”hence their name.

Geologists believe the hills were formed by the weathering of marine limestone on top of an impermeable layer of clay. Over centuries, the action of rainwater and erosion created these distinctive conical karst hills. While similar formations exist elsewhere in the world, the concentration, uniformity, and perfect conical shape of the Chocolate Hills make them a unique natural phenomenon.

The main viewing area is located in the town of Carmen, where a viewing deck offers a panoramic vista of the hills stretching to the horizon. For the more adventurous, ATV tours allow visitors to get closer to the hills and explore the surrounding countryside. The Chocolate Hills are not just a natural wonder but also a source of local legends and folklore, with stories suggesting they were formed from the tears of a heartbroken giant or as the aftermath of a battle between giants.
howToGetThere: To reach the Chocolate Hills, first fly to Tagbilaran City, the capital of Bohol province. From Tagbilaran, you can take a bus, van, or taxi to the town of Carmen, where the main Chocolate Hills viewing complex is located. The journey from Tagbilaran to Carmen takes approximately 1-1.5 hours. Alternatively, you can book a Bohol countryside tour from Tagbilaran or Panglao Island, which typically includes the Chocolate Hills along with other attractions like the Tarsier Sanctuary and Loboc River Cruise.

travelTips: Visit early in the morning to avoid crowds and heat
The best views of the Chocolate Hills are during the dry season (February to July) when they turn brown
Combine your visit with other Bohol attractions for a full day tour
Wear comfortable shoes if you plan to climb the viewing deck stairs
Bring a wide-angle camera lens to capture the panoramic views
